article-meta.aff: 1Department of Urology, Torbay District General Hospital, Torquay, Devon, UK
2Department of Anaesthetics, Torbay District General Hospital, Torquay, Devon, UK

author-notes.corresp: Elizabeth Bright, Department of Urology, Torbay District General Hospital, Torquay, Devon, TQ2 7AA, UK. Email: ebright9@gmail.com

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: The objective of this article is to describe our initial experience of performing day-case robotic-assisted laparoscopic nephroureterectomy.

sec.title: Subjects/patients and methods:
sec.p: Based on our previous experience of performing day-case laparoscopic nephrectomies, a standardised surgical and anaesthetic procedure, and patient selection criteria were applied to two patients undergoing nephroureterectomy.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Both patients underwent successful robotic-assisted laparoscopic nephroureterectomy for upper tract transitional cell carcinoma and were discharged home on the day of surgery. Neither experienced a post-operative complication or required hospital admission.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Day-case nephroureterectomy is a viable option in appropriately selected patients. We present the first report of nephroureterectomies performed as day-case surgery.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: It is more than 20 years since the Audit Commission and the Royal College of Surgeons of England recommended an expansion in United Kingdom (UK) day surgery services.1,2 Since then an increasing number of operations have become routine day cases. In particular, the progression of minimally invasive techniques has enabled the day surgery unit to become the realm of many laparoscopic procedures.3–7 Day-case laparoscopic nephrectomies (DCLN) have been successfully performed in the UK for more than five years at North Staffordshire Hospital.8 This service was replicated within our hospital, allowing DCLN to be offered to suitable patients for the past year.9 With a number of successful DCLNs performed and the increasing use of robotic assistance to complete the lower ureteric and bladder cuff excision, nephroureterectomy (NU) was considered suitable for day-case surgery in appropriate patients. We present our experience of performing our first two day-case laparoscopic nephroureterectomies (DCLNUs), which, to the best of our knowledge, are the first reported cases.

sec.title: Case reports
sec.p: Two patients underwent DCLNU within our department between May and July 2012. The first patient, a 45-year-old male, presented with macroscopic haematuria, left-sided loin pain and a left upper quadrant mass. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest, abdomen and pelvis revealed a 6 cm mass in the upper pole of the left kidney and no other abnormalities (Figure 1). Ureteroscopic biopsies of the left renal pelvis mass confirmed transitional cell carcinoma (TCC). The second patient, a 57-year-old male, presented with frank haematuria. CT scan confirmed a 3 cm soft tissue mass within the upper collecting system of the left kidney suggestive of TCC (Figure 2). Both patients were previously fit and healthy and were advised to undergo NU. Both men met criteria for day-case surgery, and preferred this to inpatient admission.

caption.p: Computed tomography showing saggital image of malignant left renal mass in patient one.
Computed tomography showing coronal image of malignant left renal mass in patient two.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: The departmental protocol currently used for selecting patients for DCLN was applied to these cases. Patient suitability based on three criteria: medical, surgical and social, is assessed by both the operating surgeon and a consultant anaesthetist at the pre-operative assessment clinic (Table). A standardised pre-, intra- and post-operative protocol is followed. Pre-operatively starvation is kept to a minimum, with clear fluids allowed up to two hours prior to induction of anaesthesia. Nutritional supplements are administered the day before surgery and pre-operative carbohydrate drinks given on the morning of surgery in accordance with current enhanced recovery guidelines. A urethral catheter is inserted at the start of the procedure. A standard transperitoneal approach using three 12 mm ports is employed to perform LN and dissection of the ureter as far as possible into the pelvis. A haemolock is applied to the lower ureter to prevent spillage of ureteric contents. A daVinci 8 mm port is sited suprapubically in the midline and a second daVinci 8 mm port is ‘piggy-backed’ into the ipsilateral pelvic 12 mm port (Figure 3), permitting robotically assisted (Da Vinci Si Robot, Intuitive Surgical, Sunnyvale, CA, USA) extravesical circumferential excision of the remaining ureter and bladder cuff around the ureteric orifice. The bladder is closed in three layers with a continuous 3.0 vicryl suture. The specimen is retrieved en bloc via an extended iliac fossa port incision. An intra-peritoneal drain is inserted close to the cystotomy closure and local anaesthetic infiltrated to the port sites. In case one LN was performed with the patient in the lateral position, with subsequent supine repositioning prior to docking the robot and completing robotically assisted distal resection. In the second case the patient was not repositioned prior to robot docking and the entire procedure was performed in the lateral position.

caption.p: Patient suitability criteria for day-case laparoscopic nephrectomy/nephroureterectomy.

tr.th: ASA 1, 2 or 3 with stable medical disease

tr.td: Kidney suitable for laparoscopic surgery — < 8 cm tumour, no locally advanced tumour invasion
Responsible adult carer present for first 24 hours and resides within one hour of hospital

sec.p: Post-operatively, oral intake then subsequent mobilisation is encouraged on the recovery ward. They are reviewed at regular intervals by both the surgeon and the anaesthetist, and discharged home when comfortable and mobilising freely. It is standard procedure that all patients having major surgery as a day case are provided with a contact number for the day surgery unit and the overnight senior nurse bleep holder, in case of emergencies. All patients receive a nurse-led telephone follow-up the next day, are questioned regarding any post-operative symptoms and asked to grade their pain as mild, moderate or severe. DCLNU patients also attend an out-patient appointment with the surgeon and the urology specialist nurse, day three for drain removal and day 10 for bladder instillation of mitomycin C and catheter removal.

sec.title: Anaesthesia and analgesia
sec.p: Patients receive oral premedication with paracetamol 1 g and slow-release ibuprofen 1600 mg (this is omitted if the estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is < 60). Total intravenous anaesthesia is used with target-controlled infusion of propofol and remifentanil. Three hundred mcg of IV fentanyl is given as the surgical ports are removed and a transversus abdominis plane block is administered at the end of the procedure. As required IV fentanyl 25 mcg is provided in primary recovery, followed by four-hourly paracetamol and as required oramorph on day ward. Co-codamol 30/500 and ibuprofen 600 mg are provided as discharge analgesia for five days.

sec.title: Outcome
sec.p: Both patients underwent successful robotic-assisted DCLNU for upper tract TCC. Histological analyses of the resected specimens confirmed G2 pT3 N0 M0 TCC of the left renal pelvis for patient one and included six sampled lymph nodes, all of which were negative. For patient two, histology confirmed G1 pTa N0 M0 TCC of the left renal pelvis. Lymph nodes were not actively sampled intra-operatively and none were identified histologically. In both specimens all surgical margins were negative. Operative duration and estimated blood loss was 300 minutes and 30 mls for the first patient and 330 minutes and 10 mls for the second case, respectively. Both men were discharged at five hours post-operatively and returned to all activities of daily living within one week. Patient one, a television aerial installer, and patient two, a teacher, returned to full employment after three and five weeks, respectively. Neither experienced any post-operative complication or required hospital admission. At telephone review the following day, both patients reported feeling “very good” with only mild post-operative pain. Neither patient experienced nausea, vomiting, dizziness, drowsiness or bleeding, and both men were very satisfied with having one-day surgery.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: NU including bladder cuff excision is the recommended treatment for patients with upper tract TCC10 as cancer-specific mortality is increased in patients with high-grade disease if bladder cuff excision is omitted.11 Due to the advantages of reducing inpatient stay, wound pain and convalescence, laparoscopic removal is now the gold standard method of performing a nephrectomy in suitable cases. Whilst laparoscopy can also be utilised for proximal NU, traditionally resection of the distal ureter and bladder cuff has been performed via open surgery. The advent of intra-corporeal suturing has enabled those with this proficiency to complete the entire resection laparoscopically.12 However, laparoscopic management of the distal section is technically challenging because of the limited angling of laparoscopic instruments. Further innovation in robotically assisted surgery permits easier resection and suturing due to wristed movements, negating the need for open distal ureteric resection,13 with some centres reporting positive outcomes for an entirely robotic NU14–16 and a length of hospital stay as short as two days.17

Whilst advances in minimally invasive surgery have facilitated more procedures to be performed on an ambulatory basis, this has only been possible due to improvements in anaesthesia. Newer agents have a shorter duration of action and a faster recovery,18 allowing patients to be awake and alert more quickly.19 Greater emphasis is also placed on the adequate management of postoperative symptoms of day surgery patients to ensure they are able to recover at home.20,21

In addition to the technical advances, patients are increasingly favouring one-day surgery.22 It reduces the risk of hospital-acquired infections, allows patients to control their recovery in their own environment and, as they are unlikely to be cancelled because of bed shortages, causes minimal disruption to their personal lives.23 Studies have shown high levels of patient satisfaction with day surgery procedures,24,25 with patients requesting more operations to be performed on this basis.26 Furthermore, day surgery has significant economic benefits to healthcare resources in secondary care7 without placing undue demands on community services.24

This paper describes the first-ever reported DCLNU. Previously published cases of robotically assisted NU report greater mean length of stay.13–17 The utilisation of a standardised anaesthetic and analgesic protocol had been successfully used within our department in patients undergoing DCLN. The adoption of a minimally invasive bladder cuff excision technique allowed the application of this protocol to NU. However, neither of these aspects is revolutionary or beyond the capability of many departments. Our success in providing DCLNU is a result of the holistic approach and team-working between members of the secondary-care team, community services and the patient. Successful same-day discharge requires close collaboration between surgeon and anaesthetist throughout the patient journey, easily accessible primary and secondary healthcare resources and, most important, a motivated patient. Our experience of performing DCLN has highlighted that even when fully informed and free of complications, same-day discharge is likely to fail in poorly motivated patients. In conclusion, we report to the best of our knowledge the first-ever NU performed as true day-case procedures. In appropriately selected cases there is no reason why this should not be the preferred option, allowing patients to recover in their home environment. Consequently, we will continue to offer DCLNU to future patients.
